newsitem.title: USA: U.S. debt futures end lower, break out of ranges.
newsitem.headline: U.S. debt futures end lower, break out of ranges.

text.p: U.S. debt futures fell sharply, as the yield curve steepened dramatically due to concerns that U.S. economic growth was strengthening more than anticipated, traders and analysts said.
"It puts the September FOMC (Federal Open Market Committee) meeting right back into the spotlight," one floor trader said.
The two- to five-year note yield spread has widened eight basis points in two weeks to 0.40 basis points.
"That's a hefty rise," said Jim Donnelly, chief market strategist at Technical Data.
Donnelly said the two-year note to 30-year Treasury bond yield spread remained steep around the 0.85 basis point level.

U.S. July durable goods data, coupled with a lower than expected rise in weekly U.S. jobless claims, raised concerns that strong economic growth in the third quarter would contribute to inflationary pressures.

Traders on the floor attributed Technical Data's consensus surveys on the September 7 employment reports to the sell-off. In Technical Data's consensus survey, the median range for August nonfarm payrolls was 175,000 to 275,000, with 238,000 as the average, Donnelly said.
The surveys also showed a range of estimates for the unemployment rate at 5.2 percent to 5.4 percent.
Donnelly said the consensus forecasts were largely based on the last four weekly jobless claims and the four-week average, which still remains near seven-year lows.

The minutes of the Federal Open Market Committee's July 2-3 meeting, which were released after the close of pit trade, showed the FOMC voted 11 to one to keep short-term rates steady with a bias toward tightening.
However, they said a tightening bias was not a tightening commitment.
The FOMC also said the most likely economic scenario was one of subdued inflation and a slower economic expansion.
However, traders and analysts alike said the market was pricing-in concerns of rising inflation pressures and was now re-focusing its attention on the September 24 FOMC meeting.
"Some managed futures guys (funds) got short," one trader said, referring to heavy selling in Eurodollars from one large fund.
March Eurodollars dropped below 94.00 and tested a trendline level of 93.99, while December Eurodollars finally broke below its 15-day price range to 94.13.
One foreign-based firm sold nearly 20,000 five-year notes and forced locals in the bond pit to cover long positions which they had established at the 109-24/32 to 109-25/32 area.
The expiration of September bond options also contributed to the selling pressure, traders said.
They also noted spread activity between U.S. bonds and notes, and U.S. bonds and foreign bonds.

At the end of pit trade, September bonds were down 1-01/32 at 109-17/32, 10-year notes were down 20/32 at 107-23/32, five-year notes were down 14/32 at 105-51/64, March Eurodollars were down nine bps at 94.01.
